title.narrative: Providing Specialized Protection Services for 100 Disabled Children at Risk in the North and Akkar – Protection

description.narrative: Children with disabilities are among the most marginalized and vulnerable groups worldwide. Confronted with social and cultural exclusion, barriers to accessing services, as well as gaps in policies and legislation, children with disabilities are effectively barred from realizing their rights to healthcare, education, and even survival. The Lebanon Crisis Response Plan (LCRP) 2017 – 2020 recognizes that children with disabilities are at a higher risk of violence, abuse and exploitation, both inside the home and in the wider community, with women and girls with disabilities being among the most vulnerable to Gender Based Violence (GBV). During the last year, ADJI assessed and documented more than 360 cases for refugee children with disabilities and more than 170 Lebanese children with disabilities in Tripoli and Akkar. These children have a special educational and rehabilitation needs due to moderate and severe disabilities including physical, mental, sensory or intellectual impairments. In this project ADJI will target 100 children from the list and from new potential applicants who haven’t supported by our services. These 100 Children at risk (70% Syrian, 10% PRL, and 20% Lebanese) are from Tripoli (Abi Samra, Mina, Quobbeh, Tabbane, Menieh, Zgharta…..) and Akkar and will be provided with specialized protection services, also we will make the effort to reach Palestinian refugee from Lebanon and Syria in close coordination with UNRWA and their partners.The project aims to provide 100 Children with disabilities CwDs (50 girls and 50 boys) with an integrated package of quality prevention and comprehensive response services including special education, physical therapy, speech therapy, occupational therapy, psycho-social support and recreational activities as well as to sensitize caregivers and communities on the rights of children with disabilities to decrease attitudes preventing the social inclusion.The services and the activities will be adapted to the disability level of the children. In addition, caregivers for children with physical and intellectual impairments face extreme challenges and have little guidance and support when raising their child. Which result a risks that affect the child protection environment. Therefore, the project will target the caregivers of these children by providing them with necessary skills to deal with their disabled children, through a guidance program that includes personal session, group sessions, training, and regular class visits which will ensure the sustainability of the project. Also, we will work with the community to decrease attitudes preventing the social inclusion and enhance the outreach activities. The project will start at 1st August 2019 and end at 31st May 2020.
